title: Reducing Risk for Alzheimer's Disease in High-Risk Women Through Yogic Meditation Training
description_brief: The purpose of this pilot study will be to test whether Kundalini yoga (KY) and Kirtan Kriya (KK) yogic meditation is superior to Memory Enhancement Training (MET) for improving cognitive functioning, health (including cardiovascular factors), and mood in women with high AD risk.
description_detailed: Overall, the investigators anticipate recruiting 100 women (50 or older) with MCI and high Alzheimer's disease risk. Subjects will either receive: (1) MET class for 60 minutes per week; or (2) Kundalini yoga and "Kirtan Kriya" meditation class for 60 minutes per week. Assessments will be completed immediately after the interventions at 6 and 12 weeks and follow-up visits at week 24 and 48 to monitor the overall benefit of the intervention.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: 100 participants were consented and completed screen visit while 79 participants completed baseline and were randomized to either group. 10 individuals were screen fails and 11 dropped out before randomization.

groups.title: Memory Training
groups.description:
Group memory training will be administered for amnestic mild cognitive impairment (MCI)

Memory Training: Participants will attend a weekly memory training class for 12 weeks as well as receive daily memory homework (12 minute duration) for the 12 weeks.

groups.title: Kundalini Yoga and Meditation
groups.description:
Participants will engage in weekly yoga classes and daily 12 minute meditation

Kundalini yoga and meditation: Participants will participate in a 60 minute yoga and meditation session weekly for 12 weeks and will be assigned a daily Kirtan Kriya meditation (12 minute duration) for 12 weeks.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT)
measures.description: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT) is a verbal memory task with 12 words learned over three trials, with the correct words summed for the Total Recall score (range = 0 - 36), with higher scores representing better performance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT) Total Recall Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Verbal memory was measured with the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT) total recall scores. The HVLT form contains 12 nouns, four words each from one of three semantic categories (e.g., precious gems, articles of clothing, vegetables, etc.), to be learned over the course of three learning trials. When scoring the HVLT, the three learning trials are combined to calculate a total recall score. Total scores range from 0-36 with higher scores indicating better outcome.

groups.title: Memory Training
groups.description:

Memory Training: Participants will attend a weekly memory training class for 12 weeks as well as receive daily memory homework (12 minute duration) for the 12 weeks.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Delayed Recall Cognitive Domain Scores
outcomeMeasures.description:
Delayed Recall Cognitive Domain score was constructed from: HVLT Delayed Recall, Rey-Osterrieth Complex Figure Test \[30-minute Delayed Recall\], WMS-IV Logical Memory II Delayed Recall.

Raw scores were transformed to z-scores (with a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1) for each test score of interest across all participants. A z-score of 0 represents the sample mean. These z-scores were then averaged to produce a Delayed Recall Cognitive Domain score. Higher Delayed Recall Cognitive Domain scores are indicative of better performance.

groups.title: Memory Training
groups.description:

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Executive Function Cognitive Domain Scores
outcomeMeasures.description:
Executive Function Cognitive Domain score was constructed from:

Trail Making Test A and B, Stroop Interference \[Golden version\] and FAS.

Raw scores were transformed to z-scores (with a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1) for each test score of interest across all participants. A z-score of 0 represents the sample mean. These z-scores were then averaged to produce an Executive Function Cognitive Domain score. Higher Executive Function Cognitive Domain scores are indicative of better performance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Memory Functioning Questionnaire (MFQ) Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Secondary outcome measures included the Memory Functioning Questionnaire (MFQ), a self-assessment scale. The MFQ is a scale that assesses subjective memory complaints. We will use the following MFQ subscales: General Frequency of Forgetting (MFQ factor 1), Seriousness of Forgetting (MFQ factor 2), and Retrospective Functions (MSQ factor 3). Each item is scored from 1 to 7 with higher scores indicating a higher level of perceived memory functioning. MSQ factor 1 (33 items) ranges from 7 to 231, MFQ factor 2 (18 items) ranges from 7-126 and MSQ factor 3 (5 items) ranges from 7 to 35.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Measured at Baseline and Week 24, change from baseline to week 24 is reported.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36-Item Health Survey (SF-36)
outcomeMeasures.description: Health-Related quality of life will be determined using the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36-Item Health Survey (SF-36) which comprises 8 scales: physical functioning, role limitations - physical, role limitations - emotional, energy, emotional well-being, social functioning, pain, and general health. Scales are scored from 0 to 100 with higher scores indicating higher quality of life.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Measured at Baseline and Week 24, change from baseline to week 24 is reported.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse event data were collected from baseline through study completion, up to six months.
adverseEventsModule.description: Adverse events were assessed by asking participants whether they experienced any negative side effects

limitationsAndCaveats.description: After March 18th, 2020, all assessments were completed remotely due to COVID-19 until restrictions were lifted for eligible participants to come in-person.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests Kundalini yoga (including Kirtan Kriya meditation) versus Memory Enhancement Training to improve cognition, mood, and cardiovascular health in women at high AD risk — this is a behavioral/meditation intervention, not a drug or biologic. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Act: Key extracted details — Title: "Reducing Risk for Alzheimer's Disease in High-Risk Women Through Yogic Meditation Training" (NCT03503669). Interventions: Kundalini yoga + Kirtan Kriya meditation (behavioral) vs Memory Enhancement Training (behavioral active control). Primary aims: improve cognitive functioning, health (including cardiovascular factors), and mood in high‑risk women. No drug, biologic, or placebo is involved. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search9

Reflect: Classification check — none of the four target categories are appropriate because they are defined around pharmacologic or biologic disease-targeting agents or drugs that enhance cognition or reduce neuropsychiatric symptoms. This is a non-pharmacologic behavioral intervention (yoga/meditation), so the correct output is 'N/A'. Supporting publications and reports from the parent trial show behavioral effects on brain structure and connectivity, confirming the intervention type and objectives. citeturn0search3turn0search8

Web search results (sources found): 1) Trial listing with interventions, summary, and NCT number (MedPath/registry summary). citeturn0search0 2) CenterWatch / Clinical trial listing with study details, eligibility, and interventions (NCT03503669). citeturn0search2 3) PubMed article reporting gray matter/brain imaging results from the trial (yoga vs MET). citeturn0search3 4) PubMed article on hippocampal connectivity from the parent randomized trial. citeturn0search8 5) UCLA news release summarizing trial findings and context. citeturn0search7
